Department of Chemical Engineering Ataturk University Erzurum 25240 Turkey In this study, we propose the synthesis of silver (Ag) nanoparticle decorated TiO2 nanoflowers (TNFs) using a polymeric conformal thin film of 3,4-dihydroxyphenyl-L-alanine (PLDOPA). The size, as well as interparticle distance of the decorated Ag nanostructures, were tuned by simply changing the number of supplied Ag ions. The resultant nanocomposite system (TNF@PLDOPA@Ag) showed unique SERS activity with high reproducibility and an enhancement factor of 4.2 × 107. Also, as an ideal photocatalytic system, the TNF@PLDOPA@Ag enabled the catalytic degradation of malachite green under visible light irradiation. Graphical abstract Unlabelled Image Keywords Titanium dioxide nanoflowers Surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) Catalytic activity Silver nanostructures Poly(L-DOPA) Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Since it was discovered by the Fleischmann group in 1974 [1], surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) has gained significant interest as a powerful vibrational spectroscopic technique and has been employed in the detection of various biological and chemical molecules [2–7]. SERS represents unique advantages in terms of high sensitivity, desired selectivity, and non-destructive bio−/chemical information with fingerprint spectra [8–10]. Although there has been no consensus on the exact mechanism of the SERS effect, two main theories are commonly accepted by researchers: Electromagnetic mechanism (EM) and chemical mechanism (CM) [3,7]. EM is the major contributor to the SERS effect and is mainly attributed to the increase in the electric field due to the excitation of localized surface plasmon resonances (SPRs) of the SERS-active system. Therefore, EM entails closely-arranged plasmonic nanostructures of coinage metals such as gold or silver [10]. CM originates with the creation of the charge complexes between the SERS-active substrate and analyte. Various simple and innovative approaches have been developed to fabricate robust and dependable SERS platforms. In most cases, the colloidal nanostructures of gold and silver are the main method for the fabrication of SERS platforms. However, the uncontrolled aggregation of nanostructures disrupts the reproducibility of SERS signals and limits their employment in practical applications [11,12]. Alternatively, to overcome the major drawbacks of the colloidal approaches, spatial arrangement of plasmonic nanostructures has been proposed via highly sophisticated nanofabrication methods including electron beam lithography, oblique angle deposition, focused ion beam lithography, and, nanosphere lithography [13–15]. The platforms fabricated through these methods could create high SERS enhancement factors (EFs) with sufficient reproducibility due to the generations of hot spots, propagation of SPRs, and light entrapment [16–18]. However, these techniques require highly complicated and quite expensive devices that produce substrates in limited quantities for reasonable periods [19]. Therefore, in the light of theoretical and experimental studies, precise control over the size, distribution, and interparticle distance of plasmonic nanosystems with 3D morphology has an essential role in the fabrication of sensitive, reliable, and robust SERS platforms [2,18,20–22]. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) is one of the most widely used oxide semiconductor materials as a result of its unique properties including satisfying chemical and biological stability, strong oxidizing capability, chemical inertness, low toxicity, low cost, and earth abundance [23–26]. Providing undoubted advantages, TiO2 has been employed in many applications including photocatalytic reactions, solar cells, decompositions of hazardous substances, supercapacitors, lithium-ion batteries, and gas sensors [22,27–34]. Over the past decade, TiO2 systems have been fabricated in the form of micro/nanoparticles, nanorods, nanobelts, nanotubes, nanoplates, and hierarchical morphologies [35–43]. Among these morphologies, three-dimensional (3D) hierarchical nano/microstructures represent significant advantages over 2D or 1D systems in terms of extraordinary shape with large surface area, high adsorption of the analyte, high chemical functionality with abundant active sites, and enhanced light scattering within the structure [35,43,44]. Various fabrication strategies such as hydrothermal methods, sol–gel and chemical vapor deposition have been employed in the preparation of TiO2-based 3D hierarchical structures [27,35,43,45–47]. Compared with other approaches, hydrothermal synthesis offers valuable benefits including simplicity, low-cost, good control over the particle size, and distribution to fabricate highly ordered single-crystalline TiO2 [35,43,47]. However, despite its all advantages, the employment of TiO2 is dramatically limited due to the fast recombination of the electron-hole pairs and its large band gap (for anatase phase band gap is around 3.2 eV). This issue dictates the usage of the only ultraviolet (UV) portion solar spectrum [23]. To overcome this limitation many approaches such as coupling organic dyes, doping with non-metallic materials, and combining with metal nanostructures have been proposed [31,48–52]. Of these approaches, the combination with plasmonic metals significantly could improve the nature of TiO2 due to the extraordinary electronic and optical properties of metal nanostructures [47,53]. Metallic nanostructure with flexible localized SPRs may offer some benefits in various practical applications such as SERS and photocatalysts. Despite some reports on the fabrication of plasmonic metal decorated TiO2-based 3D hierarchical structures, the fabrication of these systems via a well-defined, flexible, low-cost, and high-throughput method is highly demanded in practical applications. In this study, we propose silver nanostructure decorated TiO2-based 3D hierarchical structures as a robust, low-cost, and dependable SERS platform and photocatalyst to overcome some limitations related to these applications. For this, firstly, TiO2 nanoflowers (TNFs) were fabricated through a well-defined hydrothermal synthesis. Afterward, a conformal thin polymeric film of 3,4-dihydroxyphenyl-L-alanine (PLDOPA) via oxidative polymerization was deposited onto the TNFs. Having abundant functional surface groups including catechol and amine PLDOPA is easily deposited on various materials and reduce various metal ions and stabilize the resultant metal nanostructures [18,21,22,54–56]. The metal nanostructure decoration was created through the addition of Ag ions into the PLDOPA-coated TNFs (TNF@PLDOPA). The change in the silver ions supply enabled the control of the nanoparticles' size and their interparticle distances. The decoration of Ag nanoparticles onto the TNF@PLDOPA (TNF@PLDOPA@Ag) remarkably enhanced SERS and photocatalytic activities. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Titanium (IV)-butoxide (TBT), acetic acid (HAc), ethanol, 3,4-Dihydroxy-L-phenylalanine (L-DOPA), Tris-Buffer, silver nitrate, malachite green (MG), methylene blue (MB) and 5,5′-dithiobis-(2-nitrobenzoic acid) (DTNB) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. All chemicals were in ACS grade purity and used as received. Deionized (DI) water (conductivity:0.05 μS/cm) was used in all experimental procedures. 2.2 Preparation of TNFs, TNF@PLDOPA, and TNF@PLDOPA@Ag nanosystems Firstly, we fabricated TNFs through the solvothermal method similar to a previous report [43]. Briefly, 1 mL of TBT was added to a proper amount of (30 mL) HAc and mixed under a magnetic stirring (300 rpm) for 10 min. Then, the mixture of TBT and HAc was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor (50 mL) and kept at 140 °C for 12 h. The powder sample was collected through a centrifuge (4000 rpm for 20 min) and washed with ethyl alcohol and DI water several times. The collected powder was dried at 70 °C overnight. In the final step, the collected powder was annealed at 700 °C for 1 h in a furnace to produce the TNFs. TNF@PLDOPA nanosystem was synthesized by mixing 12 mg of TNFs and 12 mg of L-DOPA in 6 mL of 10 mM Tris-Buffer solution at pH 8.5. The suspension was magnetically stirred for 3 h at 300 rpm. The oxidative polymerization of L-DOPA resulted in the change of color of the suspension from milky white to dark grey. The PLDOPA deposition film was terminated via centrifugation (4000 rpm for 15 min). The collected TNF@PLDOPA nanosystem was redistributed in DI water stored at ambient conditions until further usage. For the decoration of the Ag nanostructures, TNF@PLDOPA NPs were combined with Ag ions. Herein, PLDOPA film plays a crucial role in both reduction of Ag ions and the adsorption of the Ag nanoparticles onto the TNF@PLDOPA. PLDOPA having a vast number of amine and catechol functional groups can reduce plasmonic metal ions as well as deposit resultant nanoparticles with high efficiency [22,55,57,58]. For this, 2 mL of as-prepared TNF@PLDOPA NP suspension (0.2 mg·mL−1) was combined with the desired amount of a 10 mM silver nitrate solution. To manipulate the size and number density of the decorated Ag nanoparticles, the volume of silver nitrate solution was selected as 0.08, 0.16, and 0.8 mL, and silver nanostructure decorated NP systems were denoted as TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-1, TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-2, and TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-3, respectively. After 60 min of decoration time, the TNF@PLDOPA@Ag nanosystem was obtained through centrifugation (4000 rpm for 15 min). The final material was redispersed in DI water and the suspension was kept at ambient conditions in the dark until the next step. 2.3 Characterization of nanosystems The optical characteristics of fabricated nanosystems were investigated through a Shimadzu UV-1800 (Japan) ultraviolet-visible (UV–vis) spectrophotometry. Analyses of the size and morphology of NPs were performed via a Zeiss Sigma 300 (Germany) scanning electron microscope (SEM) and a Hitachi HighTech HT7700 (Japan) transmission electron microscope (TEM). A Rigaku Ultima-IV x-ray diffractometer (XRD) was used to determine the crystal structures of each nanosystem. The elemental contents of nanostructures were measured through a Zeiss Evo 50 (USA) energy-dispersive x-ray (EDX) analysis instrument. The average particle size of Ag nanostructures and PLDOPA layer thickness on TNFs were evaluated by analyzing at least 100 measurements via ImageJ software. 2.4 SERS activity tests To determine the SERS activities, we employed DTNB as a Raman reporter molecule. DTNB could easily create a metal-thiol bond onto the silver nanostructures. For this, a proper amount of TNF@PLDOPA@Ag NP suspension (2 mg/mL, 1 mL) was mixed with DTNB in ethanol (1 mL) at different concentrations (10−5–10−11 M). The suspension was kept overnight under mild magnetic stirring at ambient conditions. The suspension was centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 15 min to discard the unbound DTNB molecules and the DTNB-functionalized TNF@PLDOPA@Ag NPs were resuspended in DI water. For SERS measurement a droplet of each sample was dropped on the Al foil and then allowed to dry in a hood. The SERS performance of each sample was determined by employing a Micro Raman Microscope (WITech alpha 300R) system. Raman measurements were collected in the following experimental parameters: laser wavelength:785 nm, spectral range:200–2000 cm−1, laser power:10 mW, acquisition time:10 s, spot size:1.7 μm, and ×50 objective. To demonstrate the reproducibility of the proposed nanosystem, 10 spectra were obtained from different spots of the sample. Also, for the quantification of the SERS activities, enhancement factor (EF) analysis is performed similarly to our earlier reports. Lastly, we performed some theoretical models by employing the commercial COMSOL software to unravel the origin of SERS activity. These models represent valuable insights by providing the distribution of electric field and relevant hot spots which contribute to the SERS activity. The COMSOL model shows the distribution of the electric field and relevant hot spots which contribute to the enhancement of SERS activity. In this model, we created a 2D model of the TNF@PLDOPA@Ag nanosystem in different sizes of silver nanostructures with various interparticle distances. 2.5 Catalytic activity tests Catalytic activities of TNF, TNF@PLDOPA, and TNF@PLDOPA@Ag nanostructures were performed by examining the photocatalytic degradation of malachite green (MG) under daylight. Briefly, 1.5 mL of NP suspension (0.2 mg/mL) was combined with a desired amount of MG stock solution to obtain a 10−5 M final concentration. The mixture was kept in the dark for 10 min for the adsorption equilibrium. The degradation of MG was measured by analyzing UV–vis spectra of the suspension at specified intervals. We employed the pseudo-first-order reaction model to evaluate the photodegradation nature of MG and determine the reaction rate constants. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of nanosystems Firstly, we examined the morphology of TNF and TNF@PLDOPA nanosystems via detailed TEM and SEM images. Some representative TEM and SEM images at different magnifications were shown in Fig. 1 . For the case of TNFs, ImageJ analysis showed that the diameter of NFs ranged from 0.8 to 1.7 μm and the average size was found to be 1.4 μm (Fig. 1a and c). Also, we noticed abundantly sea urchin-like nanospikes in the TNFs in 3D interconnected porous structure which increase their surface area and may provide crucial contributions in SERS and photocatalytic activities. The oxidative polymerization of L-DOPA changed the color of the suspension from milky white to dark grey (insets in Fig. 1). A distinctive and conformal thin layer film of PLDOPA was observed on the TNFs (Fig. 1b and d). The film thickness of the PLDOPA ranged from 2 to 16 nm and the average thickness was calculated to be 7.8 nm (see Fig. S1). However, no remarkable change was observed in the 3D and porous structure of TNF upon uniform PLDOPA deposition. After the decoration of Ag nanoparticles onto the TNF@PLDOPA nanosystems via the reduction of Ag ions, the original 3D morphology and size of the TNFs were preserved substantially. The TEM and SEM images summarized in Fig. 2 demonstrate the final structures of TNF@PLDOPA@Ag nanosystems. Upon deposition of Ag nanoparticles, the color of the nanosuspension instantly turned brownish-yellow or dark brown depending on the number of supplied Ag ions (see insets in Fig. 2). When a low amount of Ag ions was supplied (TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-1), we observed nanostructures with dominantly spherical morphology (Fig. 1a). We detected relatively lower-size Ag nanostructures with very narrow size distribution. Size distribution evaluation for the TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-1 NP system revealed that Ag nanostructures were in the range of 5 to 35 nm and the average size was found to be 17 nm (Fig. S2a). It was noticed that for this case Ag nanoparticles are well-separated and the average distance between adjacent nanoparticles was much more than their diameter. As the number of added Ag ions increased, the number density and size of nanoparticles increased as well. The further increase in the deposited Ag (TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-2) resulted in higher nanostructure size and lower interparticle distance (Fig. 2b). The size of the Ag nanoparticles was in the range of 5–55 nm and their average size was 24 nm (Fig. S2b). The further deposition of silver ions (TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-3, Fig. 2c) led to the emergence larger size of nanosystems. The size of the Ag nanosystems ranged from 5 to 65 nm and their average size was found to be 30 nm (Fig. S2c). Also, we performed some measurements to determine the interparticle distance between the adjacent nanostructures, and the average distance was found to be 20 nm which was lower than the diameter of the silver nanostructures. These densely decorated silver nanostructures with high porosity in 3D TNF structures would provide unique advantages and performances as a robust, flexible, and easy-to-tune SERS substrate and photocatalyst. To evaluate the Ag content in the TNF@PLDOPA@Ag nanosystem, we collected EDX spectra (Fig. S3) and elemental content for each material. As the number of the Ag ions increased, the content of the Ag increased accordingly indicating the higher deposition of Ag as nanostructures. The elemental content of silver was determined to be 1.7, 1.9, and 2.1% for TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-1, TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-2, and TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-3, respectively. Considering TEM and SEM images and the relevant EDX spectra, we can state that the TNF@PLDOPA@Ag NP system in a hierarchical 3D morphology was successfully fabricated via a bioinspired conformal PLDOPA thin layer. Also, the number density and the size of the resultant Ag nanoparticles could be tuned by changing the initial Ag ion concentration. It is obvious that PLDOPA thin film, having abundant amine and catechol functional groups, played an essential role in both reduction of Ag ions and the adsorbtion of Ag nanostructures with high efficiency without utilizing any seed system or reducing agent [18,22,54–59]. In addition to EM images, we employed spectroscopic analyses such as UV–vis absorption and XRD (Fig. 3 ) to evaluate further characterization of NP systems. In XRD patterns TNF and TNF@PLDOPA NP systems (Fig. 3a), almost all the prominent diffraction peaks (shown in each spectrum) were assigned to the TiO2 anatase phase (JCPDS 44–1294) indicating the sufficient transformation of phase after annealing procedure [60]. The major peaks with high intensity at 25.5o, 37.9 o, 47.9 o, 53.9 o, 55.3 o, and 62.8 o are assigned to (101), (004), (200), (105), (211), and (204) planes for anatase phase of TiO2 and shows the high crystallinity of the samples [61]. We detected very weak peaks assigned to the presence of the trace amount of the rutile phase. Herein, it must be noted that the anatase phase is the most preferred one due to its ease of production and higher photocatalytic activity [47,62]. After the decoration of Ag nanoparticles onto the TNF@PLDOPA nanosystem, peaks associated with two additional peaks were noticed at 27.9° and 32.1° which are assigned to (110) and (111) planes of Ag2O (JCPDS 76–1393). As the content of the Ag ions was increased, the relative peak intensity of Ag to TiO2 increased, showing the higher deposition of Ag nanostructures. Herein, it must be noted that the XRD peaks associated with elemental Ag were covered by TiO2-originated peaks. From UV–vis absorption spectra (Fig. 3b), no optical absorption was observed for TNF and TNF@PLDOPA NP systems in the visible region. However, a strong absorption maximum was detected UV region at 345 and 325 nm for TNF and TNF@PLDOPA, respectively. It seems that the deposition of PLDOPA thin film led to a slight blue shift [22,55,57,58]. However, for the cases of TNF@PLDOPA@Ag nanosystems, a distinctive absorption maximum was noticed in the visible range due to the presence of the silver nanostructures. Silver nanostructures could create a high SPR activity and resultant absorption maxima [63–65]. The absorption maxima were found to be at 442, 440, and 452 nm for TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-1, TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-2, and TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-3, respectively. The detected weak blue shift and then strong red shift in the spectrum maxima can be attributed to various parameters including particle size, distribution, and number density of Ag nanostructures. This result is highly compatible with earlier findings and supports the TEM images, EDX data, and XRD spectra. Through the detailed NP characterization data, we could fabricate TNF@PLDOPA@Ag NP systems in desired 3D hierarchical morphology in a well-controlled manner by manipulating the synthesis parameters. In the following sections, this low-cost, easy-to-tune, flexible, and robust nanosystems would be utilized as a SERS substrate and photocatalytic system. 3.2 SERS activity tests When the plasmonic nanostructured material such as gold or silver have interparticle distances lower than their size, the excitation of SPRs leads to an enhancement in local electric field distribution and robust SERS performance as a result of EM enhancement [15,18,21,22,54]. Also, 3D hierarchical morphology with an increased surface area creates improved interaction of target molecules and Raman active hot spots. In addition, the hybrid system consisting of Ag nanostructures and TiO2 may provide unique characteristics in reflecting and scattering and induce photo-induced charge transfer [66]. Therefore, we propose a TNF@PLDOPA@Ag NP system with 3D hierarchical morphology and well-controlled Ag nanostructures as a competitive SERS substrate for various practical applications. In this context, we functionalized the surface of the silver nanostructures with DTNB molecules via the thiol-metal bond, and for each nanosystem, representative SERS spectra were shown in Fig. 4a. For all nanosystems, distinctive SERS signals of DTNB with a highly acceptable signal-to-noise ratio were obtained and the prominent Raman peaks were highly compatible with similar studies. Some of these peaks were assigned as follows: 1328 cm−1: nitro stretch (NO2) mode, 1564 cm−1: the aromatic ring stretching mode, 1148 cm−1: CH3 rocking, and, 1072 cm−1: CN stretching, and CN bending [53,65]. Despite the lower deposition of silver nanostructures and high interparticle distance (higher than their size), the TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-1 NP system could create significant SERS activity. It seems that the isolated plasmonic metal nanoparticles remarkably enhanced the electric field since they were well-separated onto the 3D hierarchical TNFs. The further increase in added Ag ions led to the higher deposition of Ag nanoparticles and SERS activity (Fig. 4a and b). The higher activity of the TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-3 compared with TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-2 is attributed to the increased size of Ag nanoparticles with lower interparticle distance. It must be noted that for the case of TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-3 interparticle distance was lower than the average size of the silver nanoparticles. Various experimental and theoretical studies depicted that closely arranged plasmonic nanosystems could form intense electric field enhancement and robust SERS activity with an EF of 106 [15,18,20,21]. However, for the well-separated and isolated plasmonic nanosystems, the increase in the electric field is limited with an EF of 103. For further analysis, we created some COMSOL models to evaluate the mechanism of the SERS performance. In this model, we aimed to configure a nanostructured system similar to the TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-3 with Ag nanoparticles with fixed size (30 nm) and different interparticle distances (Fig. 4c). The model demonstrated that for the case of longer interparticle distance, the nanostructures provided lower electric field enhancement similar to isolated nanoparticles. However, as the interparticle distance approaches the lower than the size of the nanostructure, a dramatic increase was detected in the electric field. Also, we observed that the 3D hierarchical morphology of the proposed may provide additional SERS activity due to light-entrapment and tip-focusing effect [15,18,21]. Also, for quantification of SERS activity, we calculated the EF values similar to our earlier studies [6,7,15,18,21,67]. For this, we employed Eq. (1) to obtain EFs by using the dominant peak of DTNB at 1564 cm−1. (1) EF = N bulk / N SERS x I bulk / I SERS In this formula, ISERS and Ibulk stand for the Raman peak intensities of DTNB-functionalized SERS platforms and bulk DTNB, respectively. In addition, NSERS and Nbulk indicate the number of DTNB molecules for the SERS platform and bulk, respectively. The EFs for TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-1, TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-2 and TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-3 were 1.2 × 107, 2.3 × 107 and 4.2 × 107, respectively. These EFs are highly comparable or higher than similar noble metal decorated TiO2 nanocomposites as the SERS system [68–70] (see Table S1). The calculated EFs for the proposed nanosystem prove the high performance of the TNF@PLDOPA@Ag nanosystems as a sensitive, strong, and dependable SERS substrate for practical applications. To determine the sensitivity of TNF@PLDOPA@Ag nanosystems, the SERS spectra in different concentrations (10−5 - 10−11 M) of DTNB fuctionalized-TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-3 were collected. The representative spectra for each concentration and their normalized intensity according to the band at 1328 cm−1 were presented in Fig. 5 . The nanosystem showed a concentration-dependent SERS activity for this concentration range. Even at the lowest concentration (10−11 M), a Raman signal with an acceptable signal-to-noise ratio (∼3) was obtained showing the high sensitivity of the fabricated SERS system. In most cases, the lower reproducibility of the SERS platforms emerges as a major drawback and inhibits their employment in various applications. Therefore, to evaluate the reproducibility tests of the TNF@PLDOPA@Ag, we obtained 20 SERS spectra from the randomly selected spots of the TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-3 sample (Fig. 6 ). The collected spectra showed high reproducibility in terms of the peak position and intensity. The relative standard deviation (RSD) according to the major band at 1328 cm−1 was detected as 0.12 indicating the highly reasonable reproducibility of the TNF@PLDOPA@Ag nanosystem as a dependable SERS platform. 3.3 Catalytic activity tests After identifying their characterization and SERS activities, the photocatalytic performances of 3D hierarchical TNF-based nanosystems were examined via photocatalytic degradation of MG under day-light irradiation. For this, UV–vis absorption spectra were collected to monitor the degradation at stated time intervals. The UV–vis spectra obtained at different time intervals and the kinetic trace of concentration for each nanocomposite system were provided in Fig. 7 . For the cases of TNF and, TNF@PLDOPA, we detected significantly lower photocatalytic activity (Fig. 7a and b). Within 3 h of daylight exposure, degradation ratios were calculated to be 27% and 61% for TNF and, TNF@PLDOPA NP systems, respectively (see Fig. S4). The increase in photocatalytic performance is attributed to the conformal thin layer deposition of PLDOPA and its light absorption in the wide range of the solar spectrum [59]. The employment of the TNF@PLDOPA@Ag nanosystems significantly enhanced the photocatalytic activity. After only 1.5 h of irradiation, 69%, 87%, and 89% of MG were degraded (see Fig. S4) in the presence of TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-1, TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-2, and TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-3 as the photocatalyst, respectively (Fig. 7c-e). It seems that the decoration of Ag nanoparticles on the PLDOPA-deposited hierarchical TNF nanosystem provided a proper design in terms of 3D morphology, porosity as well as composition. Also as the content of the Ag nanoparticles increased, the photocatalytic activity was increased accordingly indicating the important role of the plasmonic metal in the degradation of the MG [22,71]. However, when the same experimental procedure was performed in the dark, only about a 10% decrease was detected in absorption intensity for a 6 h of application due to the lower adsorption effect (Fig. S5). For the quantification, we performed some analyses to evaluate the MG degradation kinetic data using a pseudo-first-order model according to the formula given below: (2) ln C t / C 0 = kt Herein, C0, Ct, and k show the initial and time-dependent concentration of MG, and the rate constant for the first-order model, respectively. By utilizing Eq. (2), the values of k were calculated from the slope of ln(Ct/C0) vs. time (Fig. 7f). The rate constants were determined as 0.31, 0.47, 0.49, 1.40, and 1.47 h−1 for TNF, TNF@PLDOPA, TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-1, TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-2, and TNF@PLDOPA@Ag-3, respectively. These values are remarkably higher than the similar composite of TiO2/noble metal nanosystems (see Table S2). Upon irradiation of daylight, the photoinduced electrons are transferred from the conduction band (CB) of TiO2 to the Ag nanoparticles due to the lower Fermi level of Ag, promoting electron/hole pairs (see Fig. 7g) [72–74]. This phenomenon results in the creation of more electron-hole pairs and the production of radicals such as superoxide and hydroxide. These as-prepared radicals are active and strong oxidizers and can degrade molecules such as MG. 4 Conclusions In summary, we fabricated a flexible, low-cost, and easy-to-tune strategy to fabricate a silver nanostructure decorated hierarchical 3D TiO2 nanoflower system via the hydrothermal method and the following PLDOPA conformal film deposition via oxidative polymerization of L-DOPA. PLDOPA performed an essential role in both reduction of Ag ions as well as the adsorption of the resultant Ag nanoparticles. The size, number density, and interparticle distance of Ag nanoparticles were tuned in a well-defined manner by changing the number of Ag ions. The size and interparticle distance of the plasmonic metal have a dominant effect on SERS activities. For the optimized TNF@PLDOPA@Ag, a significantly high SERS activity by using DTNB as a Raman reporter molecule was detected with an EF of 4.2 × 107 and robust reproducibility with an RSD value of 0.12. Similar to SERS, photocatalytic tests indicated the prominent effect of the size and number density of the Ag nanoparticles in the activity of the proposed system. TNF@PLDOPA@Ag system enabled the catalytic degradation of malachite green under visible light irradiation with an apparent rate constant of 1.47 h−1. We envision that robust, dependable, flexible, and low-cost TNF@PLDOPA@Ag nanocomposite could be utilized in many diverse applications including biosensors, antibacterial systems, and self-cleaning materials. coredata.dc:description: In this study, we propose the synthesis of silver (Ag) nanoparticle decorated TiO2 nanoflowers (TNFs) using a polymeric conformal thin film of 3,4-dihydroxyphenyl-L-alanine (PLDOPA). The size, as well as interparticle distance of the decorated Ag nanostructures, were tuned by simply changing the number of supplied Ag ions. The resultant nanocomposite system (TNF@PLDOPA@Ag) showed unique SERS activity with high reproducibility and an enhancement factor of 4.2 × 107. Also, as an ideal photocatalytic system, the TNF@PLDOPA@Ag enabled the catalytic degradation of malachite green under visible light irradiation.
